comments.commentBody: Faithful agent for Koch Brothers. I am disappointed in New York Times.

Walker is around because the Koch Brothers spent $50 million to keep him and a bunch of corrupt henchmen in office.  Corrupt little man who was shown to have no clothes when running for the presidency.  Why anyone would listen to him is beyond me.
thank you, theocrat!

Medicare for all.
There, solved it for you.

Republicans must shed an image of stodgy, whisky-guzzling and cigar-chomping millionaires. Their salvation may come either by the way of amalgamating the old Republican, Federalist, Whig, and Know-Nothing principles or by fighting for the real meaning of the 2nd Amendment, where the Founding Fathers neglected to insert only three words -- EVERYWHERE AND ALWAYS -- that would have prevented the States and municipalities using this loophole to restrict the possession and bearing of arms.

Well, however earnest Scott Walker intones, a majority of this nation's population will never have fervent trust in an individual who ridicules a person with a physical handicap, lectures women about their appearance and physical traits, encourages violence at his rallies, equates the actions of Putin with US conduct, says our FBI/CIA, other US agencies are like the Nazis, refuses to release his tax returns, has been captured in the most astonishing litany of erroneous statements and downright lies in an extraordinary short period (in our history or even in world history). I remind Scott Walker that Trump LOST the popular vote by almost 3 million. I remind him there has not be an epidemic resulting in a global amnesia. I remind him there has not been a pre-frontal lobotomy perpetrated on the US population.

Actually, it's clear the centerpiece of the Republican agenda - at pretty much every level: state, local, and federal - is to spare no expense and speak little truth - using ceaseless noise, smoke and mirrors - in a constant quest to convince just enough easily influenced, generally less inquisitive voters to consistently and reliably vote against their own best interests.

Actually, Scott -- Ronald Reagan saw the anti-nuclear protestors (a half a million strong at times, like the recent women's march) and bowed to their demands. He started nuclear reduction talks with his counterpart, Gorbachev. Please don't give us history lessons. We know our history. Is your degree from Sizzler University?  Where do you get off writing an op-ed about how to "withstand" democracy?  You are the most hated man in Wisconsin, according to everything I read.  And yes, unlike your voters, I read.  So much for you fiscally conservative, socially conservative hypocrites. How does it feel to have thrown in with a man who has five children by three different wives, two of whom he cheated on with the subsequent wife?  Yep. That's real Christianity. What's more, Scott - how dare you tout your policies in a column.  Your policies are idiotic and they have failed miserably.  Don't try to sell your garbage to NYT readers.  We're not Trump's uneducated.  We see right through you. And, we have zero respect for you. Take your lies to Breitbart.
Tell us how you really feel. (Actually, this response is OUTSTANDING!)
Scott Walker took his positions to the whole country during the Republican primary and was one of the first to drop out.  So much for his great ideas.

Hey Eric, maybe you can help me. Having gone to an anti-Trump rally, I am wondering how to get paid by Soros, et. al. Nobody who attended any of this knows anything about it. Could they all be lying? Any leaks? Help me follow the money, I could use a few bucks. At least give me a lead. Have you guys found out anything from your investigative reporting as to who hands out the cash? Where do I go?

Much obliged in advance.

Unfortunately, the residents of Wisconsin and Kansas did NOT vote Walker and Brownback out of office despite the worsening economic conditions of those two states compared to other neighboring states.  And then the citizens of those states had the hubris to whine to the rest of us about how badly they've been treated by those meanie liberals after voting for the snake oil salesman Donald Trump so he can do to the rest of the country what their governors have done to them.  Whatever happened to responsibility?

Scott Walker is systematically weakening one of THE premier public educational institutions in the world, i.e. UW-Madison. Higher education is one of the few sure-fire mechanisms for strengthening a states economy.

Why would anyone listen to him? He seems beholden to ideology, not his state's welfare.

Is it.

So they are not a burden, is it?

Or they are driven to steal food, starve because they are disabled, spread illness, perhaps incurable TB, because of having no care, sleep on sidewalks, are incarcerated, pack emergency rooms, die on the street, and, ultimately, need pauper's graves.

So the poor—disappear, then?

There is one big difference between what is happening now and what happened in Wisconsin in 2012. In 2012 it really was only one interest group ( the public employee unions ) that was upset. Even though I have never voted for Gov. Walker, I actually was not too upset that the unions lost. They controlled Wisconsin politics for too long and something needed to be done. But  today, with the potential repeal and replacement of ACA, the people that stand to be hurt is a very different constituency than the public employee unions. It is time for Republicans to listen.
First they came for the unions. Then they came for the ACA. Then they came for...
Yes, the people voted. They vote, by almost 3 million, for a strong and compassionate central government, not for Republican controlled states.

Nice photograph of labor union folk demonstrating at the Wisconsin Sate Capitol. I demonstrated there a couple of day later, when the protest was still going on. I guess I was part of a "Soros funded rent-a-mob", as Commenter Eric says. But I didn't know it. I'm still waiting for payment.

I never thought I'd agree with Walker about anything -- but I'm intrigued with his idea of drug-testing recipients of government aid. Let's start with the rich people whose taxes will be cut -- with the polluters and financial swindlers whose regulations will be cut -- with the military-industrial profiteers who will make our country strong and respected again. Let's test them all. And since we'll be invading their privacy anyway -- even the privacy of their bodies -- let's take a look at their income tax returns and bank accounts. And, hey, both Walker and Trump are receiving paychecks from the government -- so let's see their financial records, too -- especially their tax returns. We can do all that at the same time their blood is drawn or they pee in a bottle while an examiner looks on.

If Mr. Walker's proposals had been popular with Americans, Mr. Walker would not have felt forced to drop out early in the presidential race.

Remember these boots that marched in the thirties and early fourties of the past century?

These boots also stifled protests and had draconian punishments in place for organizers and participants and cracked down on them military style.

Deez boots are made for Walker and all crap talk Twitter Talker?

Trump also paid actors to attend his announcement and required paid staffers to attend and wildly applaud his first talk to the CIA and first press conference.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/01/20/even-the-firm-...

I have grave suspicions that there is a real connection between Trump and
the Russians to ensure his presidency by destroying, defaming in the most
blistering way, Mrs. Clinton. The key to all this is the British MRI Christopher
Steele, who revealed the Trump visits in Russia and has gone into hiding now.
Russia has a way of eliminating it's opposition, ergo his disappearance for
safety. This is the situation to watch unfold and perhaps the truth will come out.
I'm waiting and hoping. We need to restore our government and the stability the
American people require. This will not stand.
Could Mr. Walker's op-ed have an additional goal: to curry favor with Trump and win an appointment. So many job openings, not enough loyalists.

Governor Walker, I'm all about giving the power back to the states in accordance with the 10th Amendment to the Constitution.

But I am all about doing it in a rational, thoughtful, well-planned and discussed manner not motivated by hatred, anger, contempt, ignorance, and vitriol. I am against the assault on bedrock constitutional principles enshrined in the Bill of Rights and the time-honored institutions that have made our country so successful.

"States' Rights," as I'm sure you are aware is a term associated with racist policy and violent inhuman behavior. What many people have a problem with is not necessarily the philosophy behind what conservatives want to do, but with the way they are doing it. It smacks of the same ignorant, racist, xenophobic, class-driven hatred we were supposed to have learned from in our history. That makes a lot of us angry and frightened.

If Republicans do not exercise their temporary (it's always temporary) power with care, they will suffer the consequences and set back their agenda by generations. Right now they are giving tens of millions of us reasons to be skeptical of their intent, so pay attention to what the other half of this country is saying. We will not suffer fools who wish to jam an agenda down our throats. The consequence of this last election will be the next several elections.

There are two kinds of liars. Liars who are dedicated to crafting credible lies and lazy liars. Trump, of course, is a lazy liar. A liar who lies because he lives in a fact-free environment where lies have no consequences. You would think that as career politician, Sessions, would take a little more pride in his craft. Put a little more effort into his lying. That he gave such an obvious lazy lie demonstrates two things. First, that he does not face a credible opposition, and secondly, that credibility, itself is in danger. Americans don't have the discipline anymore, even were they to have the integrity for getting at the truth.

He lied under oath; he said he hadn't talked to any Russians.

So if Flynn had to resign because he lied to VP Pence, shouldn't Sessions have to resign because he lied to Congress.
He had full knowledge, but he forgot.

Don't you just love it when supporters of the current administration cry this is all a political witch hunt? And that includes the Russian Ambassador.

As if years of mudslinging by the "loyal opposition" and the entire campaign process in the rise of DJ Trump are deserving of anything less than scorn.

If there is a smoking gun, may if be found and let the cards fall as they may.
Sessions was just "following the leader".
